title: Bartz v. Anthropic
headline: Bartz v. Anthropic - rules AI training fair use.
summary:
Summaries: Bartz v. Anthropic — Anthropic recently chose to pay the largest known copyright settlement in history. Several weeks ago, we saw that the Bartz plaintiffs (book authors and rights-holders) and Anthropic had reached a proposed settlement of $1.5 Billion — the largest in U.S. copyright history. There are roughly 500,000 copyrighted works subject to the settlement, resulting is about $3,000 per work. Recall that Judge Alsup’s summary judgment ruling didn’t fault Anthropic for training its AI on copyrighted works. Rather, Alsup found that pirating copyrighted works to create a general-purpose digital library for Anthropic to use however it wanted was not “fair use.” In another case decided at that same time, Judge Vince Chhabria (in the same federal district) ruled that Meta’s acquisition of copyrighted materials through torrenting was not copyright infringement because the purpose of the acquisition was to train an AI system, which both Chhabria and Alsup found to be fair use. According to Alsup, Anthropic’s violation here is not training its AI, but taking hundreds of thousands of copyrighted works for whatever purpose it wanted. Arguably, if Anthropic had simply purchased the copyrighted works (likely for far less than $3,000 a copy) it would have been clear to train its AI however it chose — although, to be clear, Judge Chhabria would likely reach a different result.

Key takeaway: Fair-use outcomes may hinge on record-specific market-harm proof.
music_lens: Settlement magnitude (~$3k/work) is a valuation anchor. Push provenance audits and disclosure of acquisition sources; leverage Bartz’s acquisition-vs-training split to frame composition claims and negotiations.

title: Disney & Universal v. Midjourney
headline: Disney & Universal v. Midjourney
summary: Summaries: Disney & Universal v. Midjourney — The parties file their joint Rule 26(f) report . Last week, the parties filed their joint Rule 26(f) report after a few extensions. The report included schedule suggestions by the parties in which Disney requested a non-expert discovery cut-off for August 17th, 2026, with all motions to be filed by December 21st, 2026. Midjourney did not agree and asked instead for dates approximately 3 months later than those requested by Disney.
music_lens: Visual-art rulings on inducement and output similarity can carry over: document AI outputs that recreate lyric structure/phrases to support composition claims and push for output filtering obligations.

title: Disney v. Minimax and Hailuo AI
headline: Disney v. Minimax and Hailuo AI
summary: Summaries: Disney v. Minimax and Hailuo AI — No major substantive developments this past week.
music_lens: Build evidentiary files on lyric/composition market harm (lost sync, sheet music, lyric licensing) and compel disclosure of training datasets and ingestion logs.

title: Getty Images v. Midjourney and Stability AI
headline: Getty Images v. Midjourney and Stability AI
summary: Summaries: Getty Images v. Midjourney and Stability AI — Still no update for Getty . With no notable updates for Getty in over a third of a year, this case on the back-burner. As a final update on where we last left off: Getty had submitted a letter to the Court on November 25th, 2024 explaining its frustration with Stability AI’s refusal to participate in discovery or participate in a Rule 26(f) conference. In August 2024, Stability AI had argued that they were under no obligation to commence fact discovery until the Court issued its ruling on jurisdiction. Getty had requested that the Court order Stability to stop delaying and proceed with the case, but after several months with no response from the Court, it appears unclear when things will begin moving forward again.
music_lens: Visual-art rulings on inducement and output similarity can carry over: document AI outputs that recreate lyric structure/phrases to support composition claims and push for output filtering obligations.

title: Hendrix v. Apple
headline: Hendrix v. Apple
summary: Summaries: Hendrix v. Apple — No major substantive developments this past week . As discussed last week, the parties agreed to relate the present case to another one filed against Apple by Susana Martinez-Conde and Stephen Macknick. Last week, the Court accepted the relation of cases. Additionally, Apple has requested an extension of 35 days to file its Answer, which would move the new date to December 5th.
music_lens: Build evidentiary files on lyric/composition market harm (lost sync, sheet music, lyric licensing) and compel disclosure of training datasets and ingestion logs.

title: Kadrey v. Meta
headline: Kadrey v. Meta
summary: Summaries: Kadrey v. Meta — No major substantive developments this past week . Three weeks ago, Judge Chhabria accepted the parties’ proposed extension to the schedule. Based on the new schedule, Plaintiffs’ expert reports will be due November 14th with Summary Judgment concluding on April 2nd, 2026. This week saw no docket activity, check back next week as expert discovery continues.
music_lens: Fair-use win here hinged on record-specific market-harm showings. For compositions, build a damages narrative tied to substitution (lyrics, sheet music, sync) and document lost licensing opportunities to survive early motions.

title: Plaintiffs v. Anthropic
headline: Plaintiffs v. Anthropic
summary: Summaries: Plaintiffs v. Anthropic — Anthropic’s answer accuses Concord of attacking Claude . Last week, Anthropic filed its answer to Concord’s first amended complaint, in which it raised twenty affirmative defenses. Many of these defenses had been raised in Bartz v. Anthropic (which is discussed below), while others are new, including the addition of a “Copyright Misuse/Unclean Hands” defense alleging that Concord has “attacked Claude in an effort to cause it to reproduce their works and have publicized their successful attacks, demonstrating to others how to attempt to cause Clause to regurgitate Plaintiffs’ works.” It’s an aggressive posture, and stands out a bit from the rote recitations of other common affirmative defenses like waiver, estoppel, and laches. We will be interested to see if the “attacking Claude” defense goes anywhere.
music_lens: Build evidentiary files on lyric/composition market harm (lost sync, sheet music, lyric licensing) and compel disclosure of training datasets and ingestion logs.

title: Plaintiffs v. Perplexity AI
headline: Plaintiffs v. Perplexity AI - motion to dismiss briefing.
summary: Summaries: Plaintiffs v. Perplexity AI — Going into deep freeze. It has been several months since Plaintiffs submitted their memorandum of law opposing Defendant’s motion to dismiss or transfer the case. We’re going to put this case on the back burner until there is some substantial movement on the docket.
music_lens: RAG systems pose ongoing reproduction risks. Assert claims on output reproduction of lyrics and require link-respecting behavior; consider negotiating paid access APIs for lyric metadata as an alternative.

title: Reddit v. Anthropic
headline: Reddit v. Anthropic
summary: Summaries: Reddit v. Anthropic — No major substantive developments this past week . This case has been removed to the Northern District of California after it was originally filed in California state court. Reddit has requested that the case be remanded to state court, which Anthropic unsurprisingly opposes. Three weeks ago, previously-assigned Judge Susan Illston recused herself from the matter, which was then reassigned to Judge Trina Thompson. Given this reassignment, deadlines in the matter have been pushed back, with initial case management conference now set for December 18th and the hearing on Reddit’s motion to remand set for January 27th. This week, the parties jointly requested that the case management conference be continued to a future date, which the Court rejected.
music_lens: TOS/robots-based claims highlight enforceable access controls. Harden publisher lyric-site terms and robots.txt, and preserve access logs to support contract/DMCA 1201 theories against unlicensed scrapers.

title: Sarah Andersen v. Stability AI
headline: Sarah Andersen v. Stability AI - dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary: Summaries: Sarah Andersen v. Stability AI — No major substantive developments this past week . The parties recently submitted a joint status update indicating that the various Defendants had run search terms and produced responsive documents, which Plaintiffs are in the process of reviewing. Plaintiffs indicated that they intended to seek additional custodians, search terms, and clarification of responses to their document requests.
music_lens: Visual-art rulings on inducement and output similarity can carry over: document AI outputs that recreate lyric structure/phrases to support composition claims and push for output filtering obligations.

title: SDNY Multi-District Litigation
headline: SDNY Multi-District Litigation
summary: Summaries: SDNY Multi-District Litigation — OpenAI slams The New York Times for demanding 20 million ChatGPT logs as Discovery motions continue in advance of October 29th conference . With an upcoming discovery conference on the horizon, the parties have continued filing numerous motions on discovery issues. Last week, OpenAI had some harsh criticism for The Times ’ recent request for 20 million records of ChatGPT-consumer chat logs from December 2022 to November 2024, accusing The Times of disregard for the privacy rights of third-party individuals. In other developments, Microsoft filed a response opposing The Times’ continued effort to obtain information on its express license defenses. Defendants also filed opposition to The Times ’ request for a “presumptive limit” on five depositions per month, stating that it was unnecessary for the Court to wade into the minutiae of deposition scheduling. OpenAI has also opposed the Class Plaintiffs’ recent interrogatories which support infringement claims based on the download of copyrighted materials (evidently to position themselves for a finding like the one in Bartz v. Anthropic, which is discussed below). OpenAI is attempting to avoid answering these interrogatories on the basis of untimeliness and argues that the information can be obtained via deposition. OpenAI and Microsoft have also filed a response to The Times ’ letter seeking protective order which would prevent them from asking about The Times ’ own internal use of LLMs. Defendants claim that this information is relevant to fair use factors 1 and 4 as well as to damages.
music_lens: Coordinate with aligned plaintiffs; file amicus on market-harm factors relevant to compositions. Track scheduling to time publisher filings with key expert discovery milestones.

title: The New York Times v. Microsoft & OpenAI
headline: The New York Times v. Microsoft & OpenAI
summary: Summaries: The New York Times v. Microsoft & OpenAI — OpenAI objects to preservation order. As we discussed previously, the Court has maintained its order for OpenAI to preserve chat logs that would otherwise be deleted under its privacy policies, citing concerns that the same users who might use ChatGPT to circumvent The New York Times ’ paywall protections would be more likely to request deletion of their chat logs. OpenAI has maintained its objections to this order. In its Objection to Preservation Order, OpenAI raised three main arguments. First, that the preservation order does not serve a useful purpose because the idea that certain users attempt to “cover their tracks” is far-fetched. Second, they argued that the Order is not proportional to the needs of the case, because it would require OpenAI to make infrastructural changes to support the retention and would strain user trust in OpenAI. Finally, OpenAI argued that the preservation order was based on false premises, stating that OpenAI did not “destroy” any data, and certainly did not delete any data in response to litigation events. OpenAI’s false-premises argument cites support from a non-public declaration, but it appears that OpenAI may be relying on a narrow distinction between “deleting” data (which it is arguing is needed to maintain customer trust) and “destroying” data which the News Plaintiffs could argue gives rise to adverse inference.
music_lens: Preservation obligations may unlock ingestion and output logs. Request parallel preservation and model-audit protocols in music cases to surface lyric/composition usage and quantify market harm.

title: Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence
headline: Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence - rules AI training fair use.
summary:
Summaries: Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence — We are still awaiting the “fair use” determination by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, after the federal district court had certified Ross’ fair-use and copyrightability arguments for interlocutory appeal. On April 4th, the federal district court judge granted Ross Intelligence’ motion for interlocutory appeal off the Court’s summary judgment ruling against Ross’ “fair use” and copyrightability arguments. The Court stated that “Though I remain confident in my February 2025 summary judgment opinion, I recognize that there are substantial ground for difference of opinion on controlling legal issues in this case.” The two questions certified are “ (1) whether the West headnotes and West Key Number System are original; and (2) whether Ross’s use of the headnotes was fair use.” We’re not particularly surprised at this development. The country is watching this case rather closely because of its proximity to the generative AI training cases, and the hundreds of billions of dollars at stake there. Trying the case without considering the certified questions, and then having those issues reversed on appeal could waste everyone’s resources.

Key takeaway: Fair-use outcomes may hinge on record-specific market-harm proof.
music_lens: Court’s emphasis on market impact is instructive: develop evidence that unlicensed training forecloses licensing for compositions/lyrics. Frame publisher markets distinctly from any proposed 'training-license' market.

title: UMG Recordings v. Suno
headline: UMG Recordings v. Suno - motion to dismiss briefing.
summary: Summaries: UMG Recordings v. Suno — UMG files reply in support of their motion for leave to amend . UMG Recordings is pursuing the same amendments in this matter as it did in UMG Recordings v. Uncharted Labs . Last week, UMG filed a reply in support of its motion for leave to amend its complaint which made essentially the same arguments as its motion to dismiss response in UMG v. Uncharted Labs . Suno has filed a motion for leave to file a sur-reply.
music_lens: Label-led pleadings focus on sound recordings; monitor discovery for training-data disclosures. If lyrics or compositions appear in ingestion logs, be prepared to assert composition-specific claims and request preservation of training artifacts.

title: UMG Recordings v. Uncharted Labs
headline: UMG Recordings v. Uncharted Labs - motion to dismiss briefing.
summary: Summaries: UMG Recordings v. Uncharted Labs — UMG files opposition to motion to dismiss new claim . After UMG Recordings filed its Amended Complaint to add a third claim for circumvention of technological measures, Uncharted Labs has moved to dismiss. Their argument was that the difference between “access controls” (which seek to prevent improper access) and “copy controls” (which seek to prevent downloading and copying of material that is otherwise accessible) under 17 U.S.C. § 1201 bar this claim. UMG argued that “access controls” do not only cover absolute controls on access but also extend to limitations on access that reach “how or under what conditions a user may access copyrighted content.” UMG essentially argues that because YouTube’s rolling cipher serves to prevent the access of YouTube videos outside of YouTube’s preferred applications, it is an access control rather than a copy prevention mechanism. It’s an interesting argument. YouTube is definitely concerned about apps like Vanced that basically mirror YouTube (without the advertisements). The rolling cyper addresses exactly that point. We’ll see what the Court thinks of the distinction.
music_lens: Label-led pleadings focus on sound recordings; monitor discovery for training-data disclosures. If lyrics or compositions appear in ingestion logs, be prepared to assert composition-specific claims and request preservation of training artifacts.

title: Warner Bros. Discovery v. Midjourney
headline: Warner Bros. Discovery v. Midjourney
summary: Summaries: Warner Bros. Discovery v. Midjourney — Scheduling conference set . A couple weeks ago, Midjourney filed its answer, raising fair use as its first affirmative defense and otherwise reciting the same defenses seen in the Disney v. Midjourney case (including an unclean hands defense). Last week, the Court issued an order setting Rule 16(b)/26(f) scheduling conference with a report due November 21st and indicating that a hearing would be held if the parties deemed it necessary.
music_lens: Outputs mimicking protected characters strengthen arguments that AI can reproduce protected expression. For lyrics/compositions, pursue evidence that prompts yield lyric-like outputs and prepare injunctive relief asks tied to output filters.
